div.p: For each sentence below, decide whether it is an atomic statement, a molecular statement, or not a statement at all.

li.p:
Customers must wear shoes.
atomic statement
molecular statement
not a statement

The customers wore shoes.
atomic statement
molecular statement
not a statement

The customers wore shoes and they wore socks.
atomic statement
molecular statement
not a statement

div.p: Determine whether each molecular statement below is true or false, or whether it is impossible to determine. Assume you do not know what my favorite number is (but you do know that 13 is prime).

li.p:
If 13 is prime, then 13 is my favorite number.
True
False
Not enough information

If 13 is my favorite number, then 13 is prime.
True
False
Not enough information

If 13 is not prime, then 13 is my favorite number.
True
False
Not enough information

13 is my favorite number or 13 is prime.
True
False
Not enough information

13 is my favorite number and 13 is prime.
True
False
Not enough information

7 is my favorite number and 13 is not prime.
True
False
Not enough information

13 is my favorite number or 13 is not my favorite number.
True
False
Not enough information

div.p: In my safe is a sheet of paper with two shapes drawn on it in colored crayon. One is a square, and the other is a triangle. Each shape is drawn in a single color. Suppose you believe me when I tell you that if the square is blue, then the triangle is green. What do you therefore know about the truth value of the following statements?

li.p:
The square and the triangle are both blue.
True
False
Not enough information

The square and the triangle are both green.
True
False
Not enough information

If the triangle is not green, then the square is not blue.
True
False
Not enough information

If the triangle is green, then the square is blue.
True
False
Not enough information

The square is not blue or the triangle is green.
True
False
Not enough information

div.p: Again, suppose the statement “if the square is blue, then the triangle is green” is true. This time however, assume the converse is false. Classify each statement below as true or false (if possible).

li.p:
The square is blue if and only if the triangle is green.
True
False
Not enough information

The square is blue if and only if the triangle is not green.
True
False
Not enough information

The square is blue.
True
False
Not enough information

The triangle is green.
True
False
Not enough information

div.p: Consider the statement, “If you will give me a cow, then I will give you magic beans.” Decide whether each statement below is the converse, the contrapositive, or neither.

li.p:
If you will give me a cow, then I will not give you magic beans.
Converse
Contrapositive
Neither

If I will not give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow.
Converse
Contrapositive
Neither

If I will give you magic beans, then you will give me a cow.
Converse
Contrapositive
Neither

If you will not give me a cow, then I will not give you magic beans.
Converse
Contrapositive
Neither

You will give me a cow and I will not give you magic beans.
Converse
Contrapositive
Neither

If I will give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow.
Converse
Contrapositive
Neither

div.p: You have discovered an old paper on graph theory that discusses the viscosity of a graph (which for all you know, is something completely made up by the author). A theorem in the paper claims that “if a graph satisfies condition (V), then the graph is viscous.” Which of the following are equivalent ways of stating this claim? Which are equivalent to the converse of the claim?

li.p:
A graph is viscous only if it satisfies condition (V).
Original
Converse
Neither

A graph is viscous if it satisfies condition (V).
Original
Converse
Neither

For a graph to be viscous, it is necessary that it satisfies condition (V).
Original
Converse
Neither

For a graph to be viscous, it is sufficient for it to satisfy condition (V).
Original
Converse
Neither

Satisfying condition (V) is a sufficient condition for a graph to be viscous.
Original
Converse
Neither

Satisfying condition (V) is a necessary condition for a graph to be viscous.
Original
Converse
Neither

Every viscous graph satisfies condition (V).
Original
Converse
Neither

Only viscous graphs satisfy condition (V).
Original
Converse
Neither

div.p: Let \(P(x)\) be the predicate, “\(3x+1\) is even.”

li.p:
Is \(P(5)\) true or false?
True
False
Neither (not a statement)
What, if anything, can you conclude about \(\exists x P(x)\) from the truth value of \(P(5)\text{?}\)
What, if anything, can you conclude about \(\forall x P(x)\) from the truth value of \(P(5)\text{?}\)

div.p: Let \(P(x)\) be the predicate, “\(4x+1\) is even.”

li.p:
Is \(P(5)\) true or false?
True
False
Not enough information
What, if anything, can you conclude about \(\exists x P(x)\) from the truth value of \(P(5)\text{?}\)
What, if anything, can you conclude about \(\forall x P(x)\) from the truth value of \(P(5)\text{?}\)

div.p: For a given predicate \(P(x)\text{,}\) you might believe that the statements \(\forall x P(x)\) or \(\exists x P(x)\) are either true or false. How would you decide if you were correct in each case? You have four choices: you could give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is true or for which \(P(n)\) if false, or you could argue that no matter what \(n\) is, \(P(n)\) is true or is false.

li.p: What would you need to do to prove \(\forall x P(x)\) is true?
What would you need to do to prove \(\forall x P(x)\) is false?
What would you need to do to prove \(\exists x P(x)\) is true?
What would you need to do to prove \(\exists x P(x)\) is false?

div.p: Suppose \(P(x,y)\) is some binary predicate defined on a very small domain of discourse: just the integers 1, 2, 3, and 4. For each of the 16 pairs of these numbers, \(P(x,y)\) is either true or false, according to the following table (\(x\) values are rows, \(y\) values are columns).

td.class: r m b1 r1 l0 t0 lines
l m b1 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b1 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b1 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b1 r0 l0 t0 lines
r m b0 r1 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
r m b0 r1 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
r m b0 r1 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
r m b0 r1 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines
l m b0 r0 l0 t0 lines

div.p: For example, \(P(1,3)\) is false, as indicated by the F in the first row, third column.
Use the table to decide whether the following statements are true or false.
Find the least element of each of the following sets, if there is one.
If there is no least element, enter “none”.

p.span: \(\renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\{n \in \N \st n = k^2 + 1 \text{ for some } k \in \N\}\text{.}\)

div.p: Consider the function \(f:\{1,2,3,4\} \to \{1,2,3,4\}\) given by

li.p: Find an element \(n\) in the domain such that \(f(n) = 1\text{.}\)
Find an element \(n\) of the domain such that \(f(n) = n\text{.}\)
Find an element of the codomain that is not in the range.

div.p: The following functions all have \(\{1,2,3,4,5\}\) as both their domain and codomain. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.span: \(f(x) = \begin{cases} x/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is even} \\ (x+1)/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is odd}\end{cases}\text{.}\)

div.p: The following functions all have domain \(\{1,2,3,4,5\}\) and codomain \(\{1,2,3\}\text{.}\) For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.span: \(f(x) = \begin{cases} x \amp \text{ if } x \le 3 \\ x-3 \amp \text{ if } x \gt 3\end{cases}\text{.}\)

div.p: The following functions all have domain \(\{1,2,3,4\}\) and codomain \(\{1,2,3,4,5\}\text{.}\) For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

li.p:
\(f(x)\) gives the number of letters in the English word for the number \(x\text{.}\) For example, \(f(1) = 3\) since “one” contains three letters.
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither

div.p: Write out all functions \(f: \{1,2,3\} \to \{a,b\}\) (using two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are injective?
How many are surjective?
How many are bijective?
Write out all functions \(f: \{1,2\} \to \{a,b,c\}\) (in two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are injective?
How many are surjective?
How many are bijective?
Consider the function \(f:\N \to \N\) given recursively by \(f(0) = 1\) and \(f(n+1) = 2\cdot f(n)\text{.}\) Find \(f(10)\text{.}\)

Suppose \(f:\N \to \N\) satisfies the recurrence \(f(n+1) = f(n) + 3\text{.}\) Note that this is not enough information to define the function, since we don’t have an initial condition. For each of the initial conditions below, find the value of \(f(5)\text{.}\)

Let \(X = \{n \in \N \st 0 \le n \le 999\}\) be the set of all numbers with three or fewer digits. Define the function \(f:X \to \N\) by \(f(abc) = a+b+c\text{,}\) where \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\) are the digits of the number in \(X\) (write numbers less than 100 with leading 0’s to make them three digits). For example, \(f(253) = 2 + 5 + 3 = 10\text{.}\)
